channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Mapping the advance of the Taliban in Afghanistan
item.description: Maps of Afghanistan show who controls districts in fighting between the government and Taliban forces.

item.title: Hong Kong: First person charged under national security law found guilty
item.description: The 24-year-old had flown a flag with a protest slogan while riding a motorcycle into police officers.

item.title: Miami tower collapse: Final victim identified from rubble
item.description: The family of Estelle Hedaya say they have confirmation she is the 98th victim of the Surfside disaster.

item.title: Brazil: Why are so many pregnant women dying from Covid?
item.description: One in five women that died from coronavirus in Brazil did not have access to an intensive care unit.

item.title: Vatican's Cardinal Becciu on trial in $412m fraud case
item.description: Cardinal Becciu was once close to the Pope but was sacked after reports of financial misdeeds.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Flora Duffy claims historic first gold for Bermuda
item.description: With a population of just 63,000, Bermuda became the least populous nation or territory to win an Olympic gold medal at a summer Games when Flora Duffy won the triathlon in Tokyo.

item.title: Sri Lanka: World's largest star sapphire cluster found in backyard
item.description: The "Serendipity Sapphire" was accidentally found by a gem trader in Sri Lanka's Ratnapura region.

item.title: US combat forces to leave Iraq by end of year
item.description: The move, while largely symbolic, could provide a domestic boost to both the US and Iraqi leaders.

item.title: North and South Korea restore hotline after a year
item.description: The two countries have not spoke since Pyongyang cut off all channels of communication last year.

item.title: Assam-Mizoram clash: Why are Indian policemen firing at each other?
item.description: Policemen from Mizoram and Assam states fired at each other over a contested border.

item.title: Beach handball: 'It's shocking to have to pay to not play in our pants'
item.description: Tonje Lerstad tells Newsbeat about a rollercoaster week for Norway's women's beach handball team.

item.title: China stocks see biggest slump in US since 2008 financial crisis
item.description: The value of New York-listed Chinese companies has plummeted after a series of crackdowns by Beijing.

item.title: Malcolm Turnbull: Australia ex-PM says vaccine rollout 'a colossal failure'
item.description: Ex-PM Malcolm Turnbull tells the BBC he believes Australia's borders won't reopen until early 2022.

item.title: The Indian girl killed for wearing jeans
item.description: Neha Paswan was allegedly beaten to death by relatives who disagreed with her choice of clothes.

item.title: Kenyans sue the British army over fire at wildlife sanctuary
item.description: Some 1,000 people are going to court after a fire destroyed 12,000 acres of land at a wildlife sanctuary.

item.title: Archibald Prize: 100 years of Australia's top portrait honour
item.description: Over 100 years, the Archibald Prize has become better at reflecting Australian diversity.

item.title: How US military pullback in Iraq could benefit Iran
item.description: The withdrawal of remaining US combat troops could help Iran achieve its ambitions.

item.title: Covid passports: How do they work around the world?
item.description: How are countries enforcing vaccine passports and what can people use them for?

item.title: Is there a future for Africa's lions?
item.description: As lion populations decline across much of Africa, could community-led conservation help reverse this trend?

item.title: Tunisia: Key moments as political turmoil unfolds
item.description: Tunisia's president sacks the PM and the speaker is barred entry to parliament following violent protests.

item.title: Hemingway 'lookalike' chosen in Florida contest
item.description: A 63-year-old won the Key West, Florida contest for his likeness to the award-winning author.

item.title: Sandstorm swallows city in northwestern China
item.description: Dust clouds towered at least 100 metres (330ft) over Dunhuang.

item.title: Rockslide destroys bridge in northern India
item.description: It was one of several landslides in Himachal Pradesh on Sunday.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Naomi Osaka loses to Marketa Vondrousova in women's singles tennis
item.description: Japanese superstar Naomi Osaka suffers a surprise exit in her home Olympics as Czech Marketa Vondrousova earns a straight-set win.

item.title: 'What a massive surprise': US teen wins gold
item.description: Seventeen-year-old Lydia Jacoby of the United States wins a shock gold in the 100m breaststroke at Tokyo 2020.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Surfers Italo Ferreira & Hiroto Ohhara ride big waves
item.description: Watch Italo Ferreira and Hiroto Ohhara ride big waves as a tropical storm hits the Tsurigasaki surfing beach during the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Day-by-day guide to the key events, big stars and British medal hopes
item.description: Want to know what's happening when in Tokyo? Check out our comprehensive guide to all the action in Japan.

item.title: Tears on the podium for a dream come true
item.description: The 'baby' of Beijing became a father, a husband and an LGBTQ+ spokesperson. And now Tom Daley is an Olympic gold medallist. This is his story.

item.title: Russian Olympic Committee win gymnastics gold
item.description: The Russian Olympic Committee hold on to take gymnastics men's team gold as Great Britain finish fourth.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Ariarne Titmus beats Katie Ledecky in women's 400m freestyle, Dressel takes first gold
item.description: Australia's Ariarne Titmus triumphs over American five-time Olympic gold medallist Katie Ledecky in the women's 400m freestyle.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: German women's gymnastics team wears full-body suits
item.description: Germany's gymnasts wear full-body suits in women's qualification at the Olympics as they continue their stand against the sexualisation of their sport.
